choices.text: Watch BP & terminate when BP gets elevated
Watch for BP & induce on the EDD

questions.text: A 35-year-old female primigravida, H/O IVF done having dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy 38weeks, 1st twin breech, BP-140/92 mmHg, urine albumin 1+. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution: Twin pregnancy delivery totally depends on the presentation of the fetus in the uterus.

questions.text: A mother brings her 16-year-old daughter to GOPD with complaints of not attaining menarche. She gives h/o cyclical pain abdomen. On further examination midline abdominal swelling seen. P/R examination shows bulging mass in vagina. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Cryptomenorrhea. The common causes are:

  • Imperforate hymen(The most common cause): Characterised by a bulging bluish membrane in the hymen
  • Transverse vaginal septum: A blind short vagina seen with a pinkish concave membrane(the septum) and the cervix is not seen(Option D ruled out)

Clinical features of imperforate hymen:

  • Cyclical abdominal pain
  • Per abdominal mass(suprapubic bulge)
  • Retention of urine

Management of Imperforate hymen: Cruciate shaped incision

Fig. A half moon of thin, bluish, bulging membrane normally surrounds the opening of a young girl's vagina s/o Imperforate hymen

Fig. A concave pinkish covering situated higher up the vaginal canal s/o Transverse vaginal septum

Treatment options for an imperforate hymen include: Hymenectomy using cruciate or annular incisions. Hymenectomy using electrocautery. Placement of a 16Fr Foley catheter with 10ml balloon insufflation to preserve hymenal tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an Estrogen dependent pubertal change?
questions.solution:
Hair growth (pubic and axillary hair) is influenced primarily by androgens (such as testosterone) rather than estrogens during puberty.

The other options:

B) Menarche: The onset of menstruation (menarche) is influenced by estrogen levels.

C) Vaginal cornification: This refers to changes in the vaginal epithelium in response to estrogen, indicating pubertal maturation.

D) Cervical Mucus: Changes in cervical mucus consistency and production are also influenced by estrogen levels during puberty.

Therefore, hair growth (option A) is not an estrogen-dependent pubertal change

questions.text: A 18-year-old girl comes to GOPD presented with 6months amenorrhea, with low grade fever, weight loss, pain abdomen, generalized weakness. On examination, Pelvic mass felt on left side with features of Ascites. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Female genital tuberculosis (FGTB) is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis(rarely Mycobacterium bovis and/or atypical mycobacteria) being usually secondary to TB of the lungs or other organs with infection reaching through haematogenous, lymphatic route or direct spread from abdominal TB.

  • Clinical features: Some women with genital TB can have symptoms like irregular periods, blood stained vaginal discharge, pain during intercourse and chronic pelvic pain. Sometimes, the condition mimics other gynaecological conditions like ovarian cysts, ectopic pregnancy or even genital cancer.
  • Diagnosis: Laparoscopy and hysteroscopy can diagnose genital tuberculosis by various findings.
  • Treatment: Anti-tubercular chemotherapy is the first line of management for all forms of genital Tb and a 6 months course is the standard of care. Most patients with tubercular epididymo-orchitis respond to antitubercular therapy but may require open or percutaneous drainage.

Option A,C,D don't fit with the clinical stem provided.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant mother who had previous twin delivery visits ANC OPD for routine check-up. She is sure of her dates with 36 weeks. What is the obstetric score?
questions.solution:
Parity & Gravida

  • Parity
    • Is number of past pregnancies that have gone beyond period of viability i.e. 28 weeks gestation.
  • Gravida
    • Is the total number of pregnancies(past and present), a woman has had regardless of outcome.
  • Living issue
    • Number of living children

In both cases, twins are counted as a single pregnancy

As this pregnant woman delivered twins previously, her parity(P) is 1, gravida(G) is 2 and living issue(L) is 2 i.e G2P1L2

questions.text: Mrs Rekha having her child of 2 years presents with pruritus vulvae & amenorrhea. She gives h/o severe blood loss & failure of lactation during pregnancy. She is lethargic and has cold intolerance, she has multiple skin infections and anemia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Sheehan syndrome.

Sheehan syndrome occurs when the anterior pituitary gland is damaged due to significant blood loss.

The symptoms of Sheehan syndrome occur as a result of the low hormone levels. These may include an inability to produce breast milk, irregular or absent periods, hot flashes and a decreased sex drive. Other symptoms may include fatigue, headaches, low blood pressure and hair loss.

Excessive blood loss during or after delivery of a baby may affect the function of the pituitary gland, leading to a form of maternal hypopituitarism known as Sheehan syndrome (SS). Such extensive bleeding may reduce the blood flow to the pituitary gland causing the pituitary cells to be damaged or die(necrosis).

Management is by hormone replacement: Start with glucocorticoids, then FSH,LH,TSH etc

Option B: Asherman syndrome should be having a history of D&C of the uterus followed by amenorrhea or hypomenorrhea, but the hormonal levels will be absolutely fine with no symptoms either.
Option C: Prolactinoma presents with galactorrhea and amenorrhea and no other symptoms.It doesn't fit with the symptom given.

questions.text: 1st line of treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women
questions.solution:
The first line of treatment for Osteoporosis in postmenopausal women is Bisphosphonates.

Option A: Ulipristal is a Selective Progesterone receptor modulator and is used as a contraceptive

Option B: Raloxifene is a Selective Estrogen receptor modulator and is used in Osteoporosis but it isn't the first line of treatment

Option C: Estrogen can also help but not the first line

questions.text: Most common site for fertilization?
questions.solution:
Ampulla is the most common site for fertilization.

Ampulla: The major channel in your fallopian tube, located in-between the infundibulum and the isthmus. Fertilization most often takes place in the ampulla.

Fertilization usually takes place in a fallopian tube that links an ovary to the uterus. If the fertilized egg successfully travels down the fallopian tube and implants in the uterus, an embryo starts growing

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as emergency contraception?
questions.solution:
Emergency contraceptives can be started up to five days (120 hours) after unprotected intercourse but greatest protection occurs if it is given within 72 hours of unprotected sex. Emergency contraception is also known as emergency birth control, backup birth control and the morning after pill.

Method of choice/M/C method used = Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose (Tablet = 0.75 mg 2 tablets together)

Others are:

  • Mifepristone(RU 486)
  • High dose Estrogen

Note: The overall risk of having pregnancy after single unprotected intercourse is 8%.

Indications

  • Breakage or slipping of condom
  • Forgot to take OC pills or insert diaphragm or sponge
  • Diaphragm slipped out of place
  • Miscalculated "safe" days
  • Failure to practice coitus interruptus
  • Not using any birth control method
  • Forced to have unprotected vaginal sex, or were raped

Mechanism of Action

  • Delay ovulation-Hormonal methods
  • Spermicidal-Nonhormonal methods
  • Prevents implantation by affecting endometrial lining
  • M/C side effect: Nausea, vomiting
  • There are No C/I for emergency contraceptive

Note: E-pills are available free of cost by Govt. of India. It has Levonorgest. One new pill available world wide but not in India is Ella - 30 mg of ulipristal.

questions.text: The distending media used in hysteroscopy with bipolar cautery is

A 24-year-old married life of 4 years, visits infertility clinic with history of recurrent abortions. On further workup, she is found to be having 'septate uterus'. Which surgery has better reproductive outcome?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for Septate uterus is Transcervical hysteroscopic septal resection.

Option A,D were earlier used to treat septate uterus but could leave a scar on the uterus hence making LSCS a necessity. Hence, these procedures are replaced by Hysteroscopic septal resection.

Option B: Straussman metroplasty is a procedure for bicornuate pr didelphys uterus and is used as an unification surgery.

A procedure called hysteroscopic metroplasty is the most common treatment for a septate uterus. It's an outpatient procedure that takes about an hour. First, surgical instruments are inserted through the cervix and into the uterus.

The rate of miscarriage in the general population is around 10 to 20 percent in women who know they are pregnant. The estimated rate of miscarriage in women with septate uteri is thought to be between 20 and 25 percent. Some research shows it may be as high as forty percent.

questions.text: A sexually active female came with profuse frothy smelling discharge with intense itching. On examination, strawberry cervix was revealed, diagnosis
questions.solution:
Profuse frothy smelling discharge with strawberry cervix appearance is suggestive of Trichomonas infection.

questions.text: A 26-year-old with married life of 2year visits infertility clinic. She was put on HMG. On treatment, she developed dyspnea, abdominal pain. Her USG reports shows following image. What is the condition called
questions.solution:
Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is a condition that can occur in women who are undergoing fertility treatments, particularly those that involve stimulating the ovaries, such as in-vitro fertilization (IVF). It happens when the ovaries become swollen and painful due to an exaggerated response to fertility drugs, especially those used to induce ovulation.

Key points about OHSS:

  1. Causes: OHSS is typically triggered by the use of hormones like human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which stimulates the ovaries to produce multiple eggs. Also ovulation induction drugs like Clomiphene citrate are causative of this condition. Women with higher sensitivity to these medications are at greater risk.
  2. Symptoms: OHSS can range from mild to severe.
    • Mild symptoms: bloating, mild abdominal pain, nausea, and weight gain.
    • Severe symptoms: significant weight gain, severe abdominal pain, vomiting, shortness of breath, and fluid buildup in the abdomen or chest. In rare cases, it can lead to blood clots, kidney failure, or other serious complications.
  3. Risk Factors: Women who are younger and thin have polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), or have had OHSS in the past are at a higher risk.
  4. Treatment: Mild cases usually resolve on their own with rest and hydration. Severe cases may require hospitalization for monitoring, fluid drainage, or medication to prevent complications.
  5. Prevention: Adjusting the dosage of fertility drugs, using a lower dose of hCG, or using alternative medications can reduce the risk of developing OHSS. Monitoring the ovaries through ultrasound during treatment is also crucial to prevent it.

Following is the pathophysiology behind the disease:

questions.text: This instrument is used for?
questions.solution:
This is an image of Fallope ring applicator.

Fallope ring applicator is the instrument used for laproscopic sterilisation

The ring applicator grasps the isthmus of the tube and releases the fallopian ring into a 2.5cm loop of the tube

Tubal ligation is a surgical procedure that creates permanent contraception or sterilization. It is commonly referred to as having your "tubes tied." The surgery blocks your fallopian tubes, preventing sperm from meeting egg, effectively preventing pregnancy.

questions.solution:
The anomaly shown in the image is Sacral agenesis or Caudal regression syndrome

This anomaly is more commonly associated with pregestational diabetes than gestational diabetes

questions.text: Identify the given image
questions.solution:
This is an image of Female condom.

Other options are all different types of barrier contraceptives.

The thin, outer ring remains outside of body, covering vaginal opening. Find a comfortable position. While holding outside of condom at closed end, squeeze sides of inner ring together with your thumb and forefinger and insert into vagina. It is similar to inserting a tampon.

Option B: Male condom:Polyurethane condoms with single ring. Included in the National Family Planning Program as Nirodh

Female condom: Polyurethane (FC-1) or Nitrile(FC-2) condoms with 2 rings

Option C: Cervical cap:

Option D: Diaphragm: Dome shaped cups with flexible rim. Made pf rubber/silicone/latex.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female comes to GOPD with history of excessive bleeding since 6months, not controlled with hormonal drugs. USG & clinical examination reveals no abnormality. Next step is
questions.solution:
Causes of abnormal uterine bleeding:

Abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) is bleeding from the uterus that is longer than usual or that occurs at an irregular time. Bleeding may be heavier or lighter than usual and occur often or randomly. AUB can occur: As spotting or bleeding between your periods. After sex

Other causes— Endometriosis and other problems related to the endometrium can cause heavy menstrual bleeding. Other causes of abnormal uterine bleeding include those related to pregnancy, such as ectopic pregnancy and miscarriage. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) also can be a cause

Endometrial biopsy is a simple and effective office-based procedure that samples the endometrium to allow for direct histological evaluation. A clinician in the outpatient setting can perform this procedure independently. Endometrial biopsy is often used to evaluate abnormal uterine bleeding.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes with complete perineal tear, she gave history of home delivery 2 weeks ago, next line of management will be
questions.solution:
Degrees of Perineal Tear

  1. Mucosa, Skin tear
  2. Mucosa, Muscle, Skin tear
  3. Anal sphincter tear
  4. Anal canal tear

Timeline for management of Perineal tear:

  • 1st and 2nd degree tear: Managed in labour room under LA immediately
  • 3rd and 4th degree tear: Managed in OT under GA

If recognised within 24 hrs, repaired immediately

If recognised after 24 hrs, repaired after infection and inflammation subsides(3-6 months after delivery)

Surgical technique by overlapping sphincteroplasty and perineorrhaphy can be performed to correct the old total perineal rupture. The surgery aims to reconnect the external and internal anal sphincter so that the anal continence function returns to normal.

questions.text: Partogram of a pregnant lady is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given partogram inspite of adequate uterine contractions and cervical dilatation there is no descent of fetal head. This indicates that the baby’s head is larger and out of proportion to the cervix.

Also presence of moulding 3+ and meconium stained liquor suggests prolonged labour with fetal distress and this is suggestive of Cephalopelvic Disproportion(CPD).

Cephalopelvic disproportion is a rare childbirth complication. It occurs when your baby's head doesn't fit through the opening of your pelvis. It's more likely to happen with babies that are large or out of position when entering the birth canal.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman visits GOPD with/o intermenstrual bleeding. The USG image shows lesion with in endometrial cavity with feeding vessel. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
B.Fibroid: White coloured whorled appearance. Arises from broad base and cut surface will be irregular with surface blood vessels.

Has pseudo capsule and blood vessels supplying it are in the periphery.

A.Polyp: Fleshy, pink in color. Arises from narrow base and smooth surface and no surface blood vessels.

Polyp has a single vessel coming to its centre: Feeder vessel sign.



An endometrial polyp or uterine polyp is an abnormal growth containing glands, stroma and blood vessels projecting from the lining of the uterus (endometrium) that occupies spaces small or large enough to fill the uterine cavity. They are found during both reproductive and postmenopausal phases of life.

questions.text: A 24-year-old mother with 7 weeks POG presents to ANC clinic with h/o accidental exposure to radiation. What will you advise her regarding pregnancy management?
questions.solution: Depending on the stage of fetal development, the health consequences of exposure at doses greater than 0.5Gy can be severe, even if such a dose is too low to cause an immediate effect for the mother. The health consequences can include growth restriction, malformations, impaired brain function and cancer.

questions.text: 13-year-old attends GOPD and has not attained menarche with karyotype 46XX. On examination, there is clitoromegaly and gonads are ovaries. Which enzyme deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia and the most common enzyme deficient is 21 alpha hydroxylase.

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (Very Important)

In a female most common cause of ambiguous sex is congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

  • Infact cases of ambiguity of sex, detected at birth are due to adrenogenital syndrome (congenital adrenal hyperplasia) unless proved otherwise.
  • It is an autosomal recessiveQ disorder (if any couple has had one affected child, subsequent baby has 1 in 4 chance of having the same disability).

Physical Characteristics in Females

  • Genotype = 46XXQ.
  • Gonads = ovariesQ.
  • Uterus and vagina are present, as mullerian duct develops normally, but remain infantile therefore failure to menstruateQ.
  • Vulva and introitus are affected. There is clitoromegalyQ and the genital folds fuse to form penile urethra rather than labia minora.Q Labia majora are fused which appears like scrotum

questions.text: Causative agent for Donovanosis
questions.solution:
Option A: H.ducreyi causes Chancroid

Option C: Treponema causes Syphilis

Option D: Leishmania causes Kala azar.

choices.text: At term just prior to delivery

questions.text: Serum prolactin is highest at
questions.solution:
• Prolactin level is maximal just before delivery at term, due to estrogen stimulation.
  • However, functional activity (milk production) begins after delivery, when estrogen and progesterone fall.

questions.text: Episiotomy incision extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body. Which structure is damaged?
questions.solution:
If a medial episiotomy incision is extended beyond the perineal body, it involves the external anal sphincter and leads to fecal incontinence.

The anatomic structures involved in a mediolateral episiotomy include the vaginal epithelium, transverse perineal muscle, bulbocavernosus muscle and perineal skin. A deep or large mediolateral episiotomy may expose the ischiorectal fossa.

questions.text: In female, remnant of wolffian duct is present in
questions.solution: Remnants of Wolffian duct in female are Epoophoron and Paroophoron and they are found on the leaves of broad ligament.

questions.text: Highest oxygen content in fetal circulation is seen in
questions.solution:
Blood from the placenta passes back to the fetus through the umbilical vein, which has an oxygen saturation of approximately 80% compared with the 98% saturation in the arterial circulation of the adult.

The umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated fetal blood toward the placenta for replenishment, and the umbilical vein carries newly oxygenated and nutrient-rich blood back to the fetus

questions.text: A 22-year-old comes to OPD she is primigravida very sure of dates with 20weeks POG, on examination fundal height comes 16weeks size. USG showed reduced liquor. Probable cause

choices.text: Small blood vessels are more radioresistant.
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Dose/intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of distance of the source

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed to be Ca Cervix stage II B advised chemoradiation. Which of the following is true statement
questions.solution:
PRINCIPLE

  • All stages of cancer cervix(I-IV) are radiosensitive
  • Stages of Ca cervix that are operable(Radical/Wertheim's hysterectomy) are IA1, IA2, IB and IIA
  • Stages IIB-IV are not operable and have to be treated with radiotherapy only
  • In squamous cell cancers, before giving radiotherapy, a chemotherapeutic agent is given to increase the sensitivity of the cells to radiation called as radiosensitiser.
  • In cancer cervix cisplatin is used as a radiosensitiser, so from stages IIB to IVA-management of choice is chemoradiation.
  • Use of cisplatin has resulted in reduction in local recurrence and distant metastasis
  • Stages IA1, IA2, IB1 are radiosensitive and surgically operable, but surgery is preferred over radiotherapy for these stages because of the following reasons:
  • Preservation of ovarian function
  • Preservation of vagina for coital function
  • Psychological benefit to the patient
  • Other indications for the selection of radical surgery over radiation-
    • Concomitant inflammatory bowel
    • Previous radiation for any other disease
    • Presence of simultaneous adenexal neoplasm
  • In stages IB2, IIA1, IIA2 - Recent studies have shown better results with chemo- radiation than surgery
  • The 2018 FIGO staging of cervical CA is as follows:

Stagewise Management :
